case_name: Smt. Engammal v. S. V. N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons

facts.text: S. V. N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons were adjudged insolvents on an application of Smt. Engammal, the respondent.

anchor.surface_text: S. V. N. Nanappa Naicker and his sons were adjudged insolvents on an application of Smt. Engammal  hereinafter referred to as the respondent . They had preferred an appeal before the High Court of Madras but it was dismissed on April 17, 1953.

facts.text: Appeal against insolvency adjudication dismissed by High Court of Madras on April 17, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: They had preferred an appeal before the High Court of Madras but it was dismissed on April 17, 1953. Thereafter the official receiver took steps to sell the property of the insolvents, which companysisted of two lots, the first lot companyprising 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house, and the second lot, 8 acres and odd of dry land.

facts.text: Insolvents' property consisted of two lots: first lot 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house; second lot 8 acres and odd of dry land. Both mortgaged.

anchor.surface_text: Thereafter the official receiver took steps to sell the property of the insolvents, which companysisted of two lots, the first lot companyprising 145 acres 10 cents of dry land and masonry house, and the second lot, 8 acres and odd of dry land. Both these properties were subject to mortgage.

facts.text: Official receiver fixed September 28, 1953, for auction sale of the properties.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver fixed September 28, 1953, for sale of the properties by auction. Fifteen of the creditors were present when the sale by auction took place, including the son of the respondent.

facts.text: Fifteen creditors present at auction on September 28, 1953, including son of respondent.

anchor.surface_text: Fifteen of the creditors were present when the sale by auction took place, including the son of the respondent. No request was made on that day by anyone for postponing the sale and companysequently bids were made.

facts.text: No request made to postpone sale on September 28, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: No request was made on that day by anyone for postponing the sale and companysequently bids were made. The highest bid for lot 1 was of Rs. 4500/- and the highest bid for lot 2 was of Rs. 70/-.

facts.text: Highest bid for lot 1: Rs. 4500/- by appellant; for lot 2: Rs. 70/- by appellant.

anchor.surface_text: The highest bid for lot 1 was of Rs. 4500/- and the highest bid for lot 2 was of Rs. 70/-. Both these bids were made by the appellant who is a brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker.

facts.text: Appellant is brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker.

anchor.surface_text: Both these bids were made by the appellant who is a brother-in-law of Nanappa Naicker. The reason why the two lots were sold for Rs. 4570/- was that there was an encumbrance on the entire property of Rs. 17,200/-.

facts.text: Encumbrance on entire property: Rs. 17,200/-

anchor.surface_text: The reason why the two lots were sold for Rs. 4570/- was that there was an encumbrance on the entire property of Rs. 17,200/-. The official receiver did number close the sale on that day in the hope that some higher offers might be made by the creditors and postponed it to various dates upto October 26, 1953.

facts.text: Official receiver postponed sale to various dates up to October 26, 1953, hoping for higher offers.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver did number close the sale on that day in the hope that some higher offers might be made by the creditors and postponed it to various dates upto October 26, 1953. On all these dates, the respondents son was present but numberhigher offer was made on behalf of the respondent.

facts.text: Respondent's son present on postponement dates, no higher offer from respondent.

anchor.surface_text: On all these dates, the respondents son was present but numberhigher offer was made on behalf of the respondent. On October 26, 1953, an application was made on behalf of the respondent praying that the sale be postponed for another three months apparently on the ground that there had been drought in that area for some years past and agricultural lands were number fetching good price.

facts.text: On October 26, 1953, respondent applied to postpone sale for three months due to drought.

anchor.surface_text: On October 26, 1953, an application was made on behalf of the respondent praying that the sale be postponed for another three months apparently on the ground that there had been drought in that area for some years past and agricultural lands were number fetching good price.

facts.text: Official receiver refused postponement and knocked down properties to appellant on October 26, 1953.

anchor.surface_text: The official receiver, however, saw numberreason to postpone the sale, particularly when numberhigher offer was forthcoming from the side of the respondent and decided to knock down the properties in favour of the appellant.

facts.text: On November 18, 1953, respondent applied under s. 68 Provincial Insolvency Act to set aside sale.

anchor.surface_text: Later, an application was made on behalf of the respondent on November 18, 1953 under s. 68 of the Provincial Insolvency Act, No. V of 1920  hereinafter referred to as the Act .

facts.text: Respondent claimed sale price inadequate due to drought, stringency, offered to bid more than Rs. 7500/- if postponed.

anchor.surface_text: The case of the respondent was that the sale had been made for a very inadequate price and there had been drought in the village for several years in the past and there was very great stringency in the money market and it was hoped that if the sale was postponed for three or four months, the properties would fetch a good price of number less than Rs. 15,000/-, exclusive of the sum due on the encumbrances. The respondent also stated that if the sale was postponed for three months she would be prepared to bid more than Rs. 7500/- for the properties.

facts.text: Respondent alleged collusion between official receiver, insolvent, and appellant.

anchor.surface_text: There were some other allegations in the petition suggesting companylusion between the official receiver on the one side and the insolvent and the appellant on the other.

facts.text: Subordinate Judge allowed respondent's s.68 application on ground price low, creditors (debts Rs.30,000/-) prejudiced.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge allowed the application on the ground that the price fetched was low and that the general body of creditors to whom debts to the extent of Rs. 30,000/- were payable would be companysiderably prejudiced if the sale was allowed to stand.

facts.text: District Judge allowed appeal under s.75, set aside Subordinate Judge's order: no irregularity, no collusion, price not low.

anchor.surface_text: Thereupon there was an appeal to the District Judge under s. 75 of the Act. The District Judge allowed the appeal. He appointed out that there was numberhing to show that there was any irregularity in the companyduct of the sale. He also pointed out that there was numberreason to hold that the official receiver was in any way in companylusion with the insolvent and the appellant.

facts.text: High Court in revision under proviso to s.75 allowed respondent's case on her offer to deposit Rs.9000/-, bid from Rs.9000/-, pay Rs.1000/- to appellant.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that before the High Court an offer was made by the respondent that she was prepared to deposit Rs. 9,000/- if a fresh auction was held and would start the bid at Rs. 9,000/- and also that she would pay Rs. 1,000/- to the appellant for any loss caused to him.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave against High Court order.

anchor.surface_text: Wanchoo, J. This is an appeal by special leave in an insolvency matter. The brief facts necessary for present purposes are these.

facts.text: Debts to creditors: Rs. 30,000/-

anchor.surface_text: the general body of creditors to whom debts to the extent of Rs. 30,000/- were payable

facts.text: Properties mortgaged for over Rs.20,000/- in 1936.

anchor.surface_text: He came to the companyclusion that the properties would be worth at least Rs. 40,000/- and the main reason why he said so was that the properties had been mortgaged for over Rs. 20,000/- in 1936.

facts.text: Insolvents deposited Rs.2000/- annually to High Court to remain in possession during appeal.

anchor.surface_text: The Subordinate Judge also pointed out that the insolvents were in possession of the properties during the pendency of the insolvency appeal and had been depositing Rs. 2000/- annually on the order of the High Court in order to remain in possession.

facts.text: Supreme Court found no sufficient material to hold price inadequate, restored District Judge order.

anchor.surface_text: We therefore allow the appeal, set aside the order of the High Court and restore the order of the District Judge.
This is an appeal by special leave in an insolvency matter.

issues.text: Whether the High Court had jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the District Judge unless it came to the conclusion that that order was not according to law

anchor.surface_text: It is this order of the High Court which has been brought before us by special leave and the only question that has been urged on behalf of the appellant is that the High Court had no jurisdiction to interfere with the order of the District Judge unless it came to the conclusion that that order was not according to law.

issues.text: Whether the court's power under s. 68 in appeal from an act of the receiver is much wider than the power of the court in dealing with auction sales in execution proceedings

anchor.surface_text: On the other hand, it is contended on behalf of the respondent that the courts power under s. 68 in appeal from an act of the receiver is much wider than the power of the court in dealing with auction sales in execution proceedings and therefore the Subordinate Judge was right in setting aside the act of the receiver

issues.text: Whether the Subordinate Judge's order [under s.68] was justified on judicial grounds such as fraud, collusion, irregularity, or grossly inadequate price and whether the District Judge made any mistake in law in reversing that order

anchor.surface_text: The High Court had therefore to see whether the Subordinate Judges order was justified on these grounds and whether the District Judge made any mistake in law in reversing that order.
